sen.j: 正親町家（おおぎまちけ）は羽林家の家格を有する公家。
sen.e: Nakayama family was a kuge (court noble) with kakaku (family status) of urinke (the fourth highest family status for court nobles).
The Nakayama family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of urinke (the fourth highest family status for court nobles).
The Ogimachi family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of urinke (the fourth highest family status for court nobles).
Kanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan
They came under the Kanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan
They came under the Kanin line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.
Branch line of the Toin family
They were a branch of the Toin family
They were a branch of the Toin family.

sen.j: 本家である洞院家は室町期に断絶したが、清華クラスの家柄であった。
sen.e: The head family, Toin family, which was discontinued in the Muromachi Period, was a seiga class family.
The head family, the Toin family, discontinued during the Muromachi Period, was a seiga class family.
The head family, the Toin family, discontinued during the Muromachi Period, was a seiga class family.
Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo Period was 355 koku (approx. 64 cubic meters).
Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo Period was 355 koku (approx. sixty-four cubic meters).
Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo Period was 355 koku (approx. sixty-four cubic meters).
After Meiji Restoration, count
After Meiji Restoration, they held the title of count
After the Meiji Restoration, they held the title of count.
sen.cmt: 文末にピリオドMeiji Restoration→the Meiji Restoration

sen.j: 太政大臣西園寺公経の孫で、太政大臣洞院公守の二男正親町実明から始まる。
sen.e: This family began from Saneakira OGIMACHI, who was a grandson of Kintsune SAIONJI, Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), and the second son of Kimimori TOIN, Daijo-daijin.
This family began from Saneakira OGIMACHI, who was the grandson of Kintsune SAIONJI, Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), and the second son of Kimimori TOIN, Daijo-daijin.
This family began from Saneakira OGIMACHI, who was the grandson of Kintsune SAIONJI, Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), and the second son of Kimimori TOIN, Daijo-daijin.

sen.j: 江戸時代元禄時代の正親町町子は、正親町実豊の女で柳沢吉保の側室である。
sen.e: Machiko OGIMACHI in the Genroku Era in the Edo Period was a daughter of Sanetoyo OGIMACHI and a concubine of Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA.
Machiko OGIMACHI in the Genroku Era during the Edo Period was the daughter of Sanetoyo OGIMACHI and a concubine of Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA.
Machiko OGIMACHI in the Genroku Era during the Edo Period was the daughter of Sanetoyo OGIMACHI and a concubine of Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA.

sen.j: 「松蔭日記（東源氏）」を著わした才媛として知られる。
sen.e: She was known as a talented woman who wrote "Shoin Nikki (Azuma Genji)."
sen.cmt: 「東源氏」の正しい読みが不明です。
sen.e: She was known as a talented woman who wrote "Shoin Nikki (Azuma Genji)."
She was known as a talented woman who wrote "Shoin Nikki (Azuma Genji)."

sen.j: 寛政年間の正親町公明は、尊号一件で中山愛親とともに処分された。
sen.e: Kinaki OGIMACHI in the Kansei Era was punished together with Naruchika NAKAYAMA for the songo ikken (literally, incident concerning honorific title).
Kinaki OGIMACHI in the Kansei Era was punished together with Naruchika NAKAYAMA for the songo ikken (literally, incident concerning honorific title).
Kinaki OGIMACHI in the Kansei Era was punished together with Naruchika NAKAYAMA for the Songo ikken (Songo Incident).

sen.j: 明治維新後の明治17年7月8日正親町実正に伯爵の位を授けられた。
sen.e: After Meiji Restoration on July 8, 1884, the peerage of count was conferred on Sanemasa OGIMACHI.
After the Meiji Restoration on July 8, 1884, the peerage of count was conferred on Sanemasa OGIMACHI.
After the Meiji Restoration on July 8, 1884, the peerage of count was conferred on Sanemasa OGIMACHI.

sen.j: 実正は、埼玉県知事、侍従長、賞勲局総裁を歴任した。
sen.e: Sanemasa filled various posts including the Governor of the Saitame Prefecture, Grand Chamberlain and President of Decoration Bureau.
Sanemasa filled various posts including the Governor of the Saitame Prefecture, Grand Chamberlain, and President of the Decoration Bureau.
Sanemasa filled various posts including the Governor of Saitama Prefecture, Grand Chamberlain, and President of the Decoration Bureau.
